passages.text: Rating Change: BUY | PO: 23.00 EUR | Price: 20.30 EUR

We think the Italian wind operator's lower investment intensity and higher income potential can yield dividends for investors, especially as relative growth looks decently priced (9x 2y forward EV/EBITDA vs 12x for EDPR) and rates are coming down (we forecast 250bps spreads to 10y Italian sovereign, with upside from dividends or share buy- backs). In addition, wind speeds are now recovering. We upgrade ERG to Buy from Neutral with a new €23 PO, offering \(- 20\%\) total return potential (of which \(- 6\%\) dividend yield in 2026E).

Poor European wind conditions (dunkelflaute in 2024) have persisted into 2025 but were already the reason for more cautious guidance at FY24 results. Numbers (and share prices) have already rebased, but wind speeds are now returning to normal and were even up \(12 - 14\%\) yoy in July for Italy and France ( \(60\%\) of operating capacity). This means 2025 guidance should be achieved and 2026 growth would mechanically benefit from the recovery. We are \(7\%\) above consensus EBITDA by 2027E, with limited pipeline additions.

ERG is keen to highlight its strategy of "value over volume", and we forecast limited capacity additions (180MW on average over 2025- 27 vs 475MW 2023- 25) with potential upside should Fer X auctions (in late 2025) settle at decent prices. Management also commented that "European OEMs are becoming more aggressive to prevent Chinese competition", which could reverse the wind capex inflation of recent years. Thus, EBITDA could accelerate, but better spreads must materialise to compete with capital returns.

Our 2026E EBITDA is \(4\%\) higher thanks to wind recovery phasing but our 2025 and 2027 estimates are unchanged. Our new PO is €23 (€19.5 prior) and benefits from a better EV/EBITDA fair value (on higher 9x 2026E multiple vs 8x prior, given the de-risked profile), a higher DDM fair value (on increased DPS growth from deleveraging - with a higher PO share given income profile), but a lower SOTP fair value (modest pipeline discount vs none before, more fairly aligned with our coverage for baseline pipeline execution risks). See pages 10- 12 for details on PO and estimate changes.
\\* For full definitions of Qmethod measures, see page 17.

We think the Italian wind operator's lower investment intensity and higher income potential can yield dividends for investors, especially as relative growth looks decently priced and rates are expected to come down. Therefore, we upgrade ERG to BuyWith a new €23 PO, offering \(\sim 20\%\) total return potential (of which \(\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{2}\) dividend yield in 2026E).

ERG stands out across our pure- play renewable coverage with the lowest relative investment intensity. Indeed, we expect €245m of investments on average over the next 5 years, compared to €560m over the last 5 years (see Exhibit 1). Lower investments come as the company focuses on value over volume, not unlike the rest of the sector. We think this is a pragmatic approach that is relevant in the current climate of limited value creation spread improvement (see our Bloated AI- petite report).

ERG plans to spend less than half its current capitalisation over the next 5 years, while established players are closer to \(90\%\) on average (Acciona Energia, EDPR and Orsted - see Exhibit 2). We are conscious that said established players, unlike ERG, are also heavily reliant on asset rotations to reduce their net investment burden, but this means execution risks on two pipelines (deployments + asset rotations) rather than one.
Exhibit 1: We expect ERG to spend less than all other renewables ... Gross pipeline capex (€m)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates
Exhibit 2: ... both in absolute and relative terms Gross pipeline capex as multiple of current capitalisation
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg

ERG's lower investment intensity is not a result of too- high leverage. We estimate that economic leverage (with adjustments for leases, hybrids, capex, tax equity, provisions, and some other smaller items) to EBITDA (excluding asset rotation gains) is below 5x for 2025 (Exhibit 3), lower than Acciona Energia at 5x and well below EDPR at 8.5x.

On ERG company- defined leverage (which excludes leases), we forecast gearing to come down from 3.4x in 2024 to below 3x already in 2026 and further to 2x by 2029 on low investment intensity and compared to a 4x company threshold (Exhibit 4).
Exhibit 3: ERG-adjusted leverage looks adequateNet debt = financial + leases, Economic including other debt items
Source:BofA Global Research estimates,company report
Exhibit 4: ERG leverage is coming down given low capex
Source:BofA Global Research estimates,company report

ERG offers a unique investment proposition across renewable pure-players in Europe, in our view, given a more explicit and significant remuneration policy. This is easily understood given the shareholder structure, with the founding and controlling Garronemondini family somewhat dependent on cash distribution at ERG for income as well as funding for external ventures. ERG's current remuneration policy is a €1 dividend floor with potential upside from buybacks (with \(10\%\) capital authorisation from the board), meaning potential income upside from both.

We think that the family, while able to further monetize its \(- 32\%\) effective stake for further income, has limited reasons to do this near- term. Indeed, while retaining control through a 51- 49 JV (with a total \(62.5\%\) ownership in ERG) with IFM Investors (an Australian infrastructure investment fund), we think that current valuation could be perceived as too low, as the IFM investment was originally made in June 2022, when ERG shares were trading above €30, \(50\%\) higher than current levels.

Given the company's rapid de- leveraging, and assuming management retains some flexibility with 3.5x company- defined leverage (against a 4x threshold), we think ERG could re- lever the balance sheet by almost €1.5bn by the end of the decade (and close to €2.0bn at 4x - see Exhibit 5).

Assuming an extra dividend distribution across the years to match this 3.5x leverage target would mean total distribution per share could more than double from €1.3 in 2024 to €3.1 on average until the end of the decade (Exhibit 6).
This would mean ERG could distribute more than €3bn over the 2025- 30 period, virtually \(100\%\) of its current market capitalisation.
Exhibit 5: Significant re-leveraging upside at 3.5x already Company definition net debt = financial net debt ex leases (€m) 2024-30E
Source:BofA Global Research estimates,company report
Exhibit 6: At 3.5x leverage, we think dividends could more than double DPS, potential extra DPS and completed share buybacks (€/sh) 2024-30E
Source:BofA Global Research estimates,company report

We also note that the company has recently amended its shareholder remuneration framework, removing the €1.3 per share dividend cap at FY24 results and now offering full flexibility from incremental dividend or share buybacks beyond the €1 floor (authorisation for up to \(10\%\) of capital, to be decided before year-end).

Our forecasts currently assume €0.1 incremental dividend per share over the coming years, with no new share buyback announced so far (see Exhibit 7). We see shareholder returns growing from \(4.4\%\) over the last 5 years to close to \(8\%\) in 5 years (assuming a stable share price - see Exhibit 8).
Exhibit 7: We expect ERG to gradually ramp up dividend payments Paid dividends and share buybacks (€m) 2020-30E
Source:BofA Global Research estimates,company report
Exhibit 8: Yield is attractive and will grow (at a stable share price) Dividends + share buybacks as % of Y-1 capitalisation, 2020-30E
Source:BofA Global Research estimates,company report

We also flag that ERG's income profile (6% dividend yield in 2026E) is looking increasingly interesting relative to domestic yields. BofA's latest economic forecasts (see report) are for German yields to drop from the current \(2.7\%\) level to \(2\%\) in the coming quarters and to remain there across 2026. Given Italian spreads have improved over the last 3 years (Exhibit 10), it would seem reasonable to expect similar trends for Italian sovereign yields, currently at \(3.5\%\) against Eurozone yields at \(2.6\%\) (see Exhibit 9).
Exhibit 9: European yields have stayed higher for longer but BofA expects German yields (and Europe) to come down 50bps near-term Italian and Eurozone 10-year yields (%) Jan-05-Jan-25
Exhibit 10: Italian yields have tightened compared to Europe, back to levels last seen in mid-2021 and 2015 Italian 10Y spread to Eurozone 10-year yields (pp) Jan-05-Jan-25

Given ERG's lower investment intensity, it is not surprising it has more modest growth prospects than the rest of our pure- play coverage. However, its current portfolio concentration (with a lot of wind assets in Italy) also means that 2025E EBITDA is depressed by poor load factors. This should mechanically reverse in 2026, with 2025 benefiting already from load normalisation against end- 2024 (see Exhibit 11).

Bottom- line, we argue the \(>5\%\) EBITDA 3y CAGR from 2026E is attractive as it looks relatively more secured than peers', given lower execution risks (over a bigger pipeline and given associated asset rotations at peers) and growth upside from a stronger balance sheet. However, better spreads need to materialise from good auctions in Italy (Fer X expected before year- end) or lower capex (with positive comments on European OEM pricing made by management at Q2 results) to compete with capital returns.
Exhibit 11: ERG EBITDA to recover from poor wind in 2025 ERG EBITDA 2024-27 bridge (Em)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates
Exhibit 12: Growth is more modest but relatively more secured BofA pure-play renewables EBITDA CAGR 25-27E and 26-28E
Source: BofA Global Research estimates Note: ANE EBITDA CAGR in 2025-27 restated for hydro one-offs in 2025 Note: Greenergy and Solaria are off charts given \(>30\%\) CAGR
Investor concerns over poor European wind speeds have been warranted over the last year, affecting \(- 80\%\) of operating capacity for ERG, down \(- 5\%\) across Europe in 1H25.

However, wind speeds are now picking up and are \(+12\%\) better in July for Italy \((- 40\%\) of operating capacity - see Exhibit 13) and \(+14\%\) for France \((- 20\%\) of operating capacity - see Exhibit 14). This should alleviate concerns over the rest of the year for now, as management is confident it can reach the mid- point of guidance at historical averages.
Exhibit 13: Italian wind speeds picking up, with \(+12\%\) in July Average wind speeds in Italy (m/s) 2023-25 and 30y normal
Exhibit 14: French wind speeds picking up, with \(+14\%\) in July Average wind speeds in France (m/s) 2023-25 and 30y normal

We use the below screen (see Exhibit 15) to plot our coverage based on our EV adjustments (meaning multiples are more expensive compared to Bloomberg's EV bridge) and forecasts (higher than consensus as we fully model pipeline growth). We further plot valuation at our PO.

ERG looks attractively priced compared to our coverage of pure- play renewables, and against Acciona Energia (similar multiple but better growth) and EDPR (similar growth but lower multiple) both rated Underperform. ERG also looks relatively attractively priced compared to the sector (slightly higher multiple but higher growth) and clean energy transition names (similarly).

Exhibit 15: ERG looks attractively priced against EDPR, ANE but also utilities and clean energy European renewables vs Utility sector and Clean Energy Transition index 2y forward EV/EBITDA and CAGR (Bloomberg consensus)

BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Indeed, we think that ERG looks attractively priced against the wider sector, trading only at a modest \(8\% \mathrm{Y} + 1\) forward EV/EBITDA (see Exhibit 16) despite better growth and acceleration potential. We advise against looking back too much in history (given the ESG investment 'bubble' starting in 2020 and significant change in the profile across the period, \(80\%\) of capital employed in wind and solar in 2014, \(65\%\) in 2018, with hydro assets acquired in 2015, \(100\%\) in 2021 with hydro and other legacy assets sold). However, we would still highlight the attractive income profile at \(>5\%\) yield compared to \(Exhibit 16: ERG has a modest premium to sector despite better growth ERG Y+1 EV/EBITDA (Bloomberg consensus) and 5y average and range (+/- 1std) against Utility sector, 2015-25
Exhibit 17: ERG income profile is compelling against equities

We use the below chart (see Exhibit 19) to plot our own estimate of net operational assets and pipeline values (blue bars) as a share of our PO (rebased to 100 at the red dotted line) and against current share price (red dots). Taking Acciona Energia, our PO is mostly composed of operational assets (big dark blue bar) and shows that the market overestimates said operational value and/or pipeline valuation and/or underestimates liabilities (where we understand we have a more conservative and granular view than consensus, as we don't limit our scope to net financial debt). This supports our Underperform rating on Acciona Energia and even more so on EDPR. Conversely, it also supports our Buy rating on ERG given its market valuation is lower than our valuation of its operations and risk-adjusted pipeline (and with pipeline the most moderate share of SOTP mixes across our coverage).
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 19: We think the market is overestimating Acciona Energia and EDPR valuations BofA renewables pure-players BofA SOTP valuation mix vs current share price (as % PO)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates Note: Greenergy operational value is negative from high capex and debt phasing in the Atacama project

Consensus revisions have been poor for ERG and down \(- 3.5\%\) on average over the last 12 months across 2025, 2026 and 2027. We are slightly below consensus for 2025E (within guidance of €540- 600m) and slightly ahead for 2026E (against guidance of \(>€600m\) ), but \(7\%\) ahead by 2027E despite limited pipeline growth (see Exhibit 20).

Short interest at ERG rose significantly in June 2025 from \(5\%\) towards \(13\%\) (the shares went ex dividend on 25 May - see Exhibit 21) and as poor wind performance in Europe continued (our conversations with investors revealed concerns about a potential guidance downgrade). However, guidance was reiterated at Q2 results and looks relatively secure to us, while wind speeds are picking up.
Exhibit 20: We are \(7\%\) ahead of 2027E consensus EBITDA ERG consensus EBITDA revisions vs BofA (Em) Aug 24 to Aug 25
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg
Exhibit 21: Short interest has recently spiked to \(13\%\) ERG short interest (% free float) Jul 22 to Jul 25
Source: BofA Global Research
We make marginal changes to our estimates. Our operational forecasts benefit from mark- to- market pricing for Italy, our pipeline suffers from phasing with lower MWh
overall (and more storage within this), but our resulting EBITDA is broadly unchanged, albeit with lower capex driving lower net debt.
Exhibit 22: We lower pipeline growth, but EBITDA is broadly unchanged from better operations Changes in ERG estimates (Em, %)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates

We have slightly amended our valuation methodology. We now use an equally- weighted average of a SOTP, a EV/EBITDA and a DDM (vs 40- 40- 20% share) as we think the strong income profile should be better reflected.

For our SOTP, we have restated our pipeline discounts to \(12.5\%\) to 2030E and \(37.5\%\) beyond (compared to \(0\%\) and \(50\%\) ) given the lower pipeline in our forecasts but commensurate with the discount used at Acciona Energia and EDPR (25% and \(75\%\) respectively), though adjusted for relative growth (half the investment intensity at ERG compared to Acciona Energia and EDPR).

For our EV/EBITDA multiple, we now use a 9x target 2026 Y+1 EV/EBITDA compared to 8x before. We have raised our multiple as we expect the market to reward the more cautious approach with income upside and/or accelerated growth potential on declining leverage. Note that ERG has been trading on 9x Y+1 EV/EBITDA multiples for the last 2 years, while EDPR has been on 10x. We therefore think this multiple could further expand as rates come down.

For our DDM, we have raised our expected DPS for 2025 onwards, with a new 2024- 30 CAGR of \(8\%\) compared to \(6\%\) , as we balance capex and shareholder returns. We have also amended our terminal payout to \(80\%\) with \(3.5\%\) growth (aligned with risk- free rates) compared to \(60\%\) with \(4.0\%\) , as we assume steady state afterwards.
Overall, our PO rises to €23 from €19.5.

Our PO for Acciona Energia is derived from an equally- weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables. Our resulting PO is €17.5.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(7 - 8\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and medium- term asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(50\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 25\%\) and beyond by \(- 75\%\) (our base discount across our renewable coverage).

For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 8x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs \(8.5x Y+1\) median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables as well as caution on gross deployments and asset rotations more specifically for Acciona Energia.

Upside/downside to our PO are: wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.

Our PO for EDPR is derived from an equally weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables. Our resulting PO is €7.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(6 - 6.5\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(30\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 25\%\) and beyond by \(- 75\%\) (our base discount across our renewable coverage).
For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 10x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs \(8.2x Y+1\) median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables.

Upside/downside to our PO are wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.

Our PO for ERG is derived from an equally weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based), a group EV/EBITDA multiple, and a DDM, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables (with a DDM added given ERG 'yieldco' profile). Our resulting PO is €23.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(6.5 - 7.5\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and no asset rotation gains. We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 13\%\) and beyond by \(- 38\%\) (half the base discount used across our renewable coverage given lower relative growth ambitions).
For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 9x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs \(8.8x Y+1\) median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables but a de- risked profile more specifically for ERG.
For our DDM, we use \(8.5\%\) CoE with terminal \(80\%\) payout and \(3.5\%\) growth.
Upside/downside risks to our PO are: wind load factors, power prices, renewables capex,

expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector - as well as dividend or share buy-backs more specifically for ERG.
